subsection.title: What are Data?
subsection.p: Our goal for this section is to analyze dataThe word data is plural and a single piece of data is called datum. numerically and to display it using various graphs and tables ( Pie Chart and Frequency Table). Describing data is a bit like describing a paintingthere's more than one way to look at it. While we will have a certain method for approaching things, feel free to get creative and take risks!
We will consider three primary types of data in this text. This is hardly an exhaustive list of all types of data, but it gives us a decent start!

statement.p: Quantitative data describes a trait/feature of a population using only numbers. Quantitative data can be either continuous if the values can be anything inside an interval or continuum (think decimals) or discrete if the values increase in jumps (think whole numbers).

notation.description: A description of a population using numbers

example.title: Quantitative Data
example.p: We can describe the length of a pencil using centimeters. Since we are using a number to do so, the length would be considered quantitative data. More specifically, since we can have measurements like 4.75, length here is continuous quantiative data.

statement.p: Qualitative data describes a trait/feature of a population using qualities or categoriesQualitative variables are sometimes called categorical variables.

notation.description: A description of a population using qualities or categories

subsection.p: Both quantitative data and qualitative data can be used to describe the same trait of an individual. However, quantitative data describe the trait using number while qualitative data describe the trait using words.

example.title: Qualititative Data
example.p: Suppose we are curious about the flavor distribution of Skittles. To do this, we could record the flavor of each candy in large bag. Since the flavors are categories (e.g. Lime or Orange), this is qualitative or categorical data.

subsection.p: No better way to learn than to try!

subsection.p: NOTE: Units are important here as it will help us distinguish between the type of data. For example, I can describe temperature as either quantitative data ( 98) or as qualitative data ( warm or cold).

statement.p: Explain how to measure the variable ``height" using both quantitative or qualitative data.

Our final type of data that we will consider is ordinal data. Much like quantitative data, this data type describes the trait/feature of a population using numbers. However, ordinal data, as the name suggests, also has a built in ordering system.

notation.description: A description of a population using ordered numbers

subsection.p: If you have ever rated your pain on a scale of 1 to 5 at the doctor's office, then you have used ordinal data before. This may also surprise you, but zip codes are also ordinal data! I'll leave it to you to determine how the numbers are ordered.
